question:
Please help me translate the content of the following webpage to Chinese (Traditional, Hong Kong):

```


Welcome to nk2028 - Expert in Computational Linguistics

Welcome to nk2028
=================
Overview
--------
At nk2028, we believe in the power of technology to unlock the mysteries of language and communication. With our expertise in computational linguistics, we strive to build tools that make it easier for researchers, students, and language enthusiasts to access, analyse, and understand our languages.
Our expertise spans a diverse array of linguistic disciplines, but we have gained recognition for our exceptional work in CJKV (Chinese, Japanese, Korean, and Vietnamese) historical linguistics. Our commitment to excellence in this field has established us as a leader in this domain. In addition, our team is actively exploring new possibilities in the realm of modern Chinese and other languages, contributing to our ongoing commitment to advancing the field of language processing.
Projects
--------
For a comprehensive list of our projects, please visit our GitHub page at <https://github.com/nk2028>. Our repository of computational linguistics projects is constantly growing, and we invite you to explore and learn more about our work.
Contact
-------
If you have any questions or would like to get in touch with us, please email us at [support@nk2028.shn.hk](mailto:support@nk2028.shn.hk).
Join Us
-------
We are always looking for talented and passionate individuals to join our team. If you are interested in working with us on cutting-edge computational linguistics projects, please don't hesitate to send an email to [support@nk2028.shn.hk](mailto:support@nk2028.shn.hk). We look forward to hearing from you!


```

answer:
In a certain kingdom, in the Trigonometric State, there lived a Ruler. Pink, transparent, shiny. The plump Protractor, the slender Compass, and the simple Pencil admired her. Despite her young age, the Ruler was not at all romantic, but, on the contrary, very pragmatic. She constantly measured her admirers. After all, it was necessary to choose the most worthy one.
Take the Protractor, for example. He is a bit old, of course, and clumsy, but he has such connections, he is so respectable and wealthy. He is so ubiquitous, has been in all corners, knows everything about life. The Compass. Everyone likes him. Slim, young. But there are always flirty girls around him, and he follows them around in circles. He will eventually change and leave. The Pencil? Well, everything is clear here. Nothing to weigh. Simple, unnoticed, poor. He follows her like a shadow and draws bouquets of roses. How vulgar!
The Ruler looked closely, measured, calculated for a long time. But necessity is the mother of invention. She ended up marrying the Protractor. They lived carefree and almost happily. But routine set in: she measures lines all the time, he â€“ angles. No feelings. No surprises. They tolerated each other and parted peacefully.
Her second husband was the magnificent Compass. At first, everything was delightful. They shone together at parties and enjoyed their youth. But more and more often he danced not with her, and she became less transparent and subtly faded away. This break-up was more painful. The Ruler became sad, pensive, somewhat lost.
One day, the Pencil dared to approach her again. As always, he had a bouquet of drawn roses. The Ruler noticed with surprise that the flowers looked almost alive. And she also remembered that not once did the same bouquet repeat itself. They started dating. How beautiful, clear lines he drew next to her! How necessary and skillful she seemed next to him! And nothing ever repeated: neither flowers nor lines. And how wonderfully he drew her! And who said the Pencil was simple? He was magical. Better than any colored one. And the most dear. Of course, for her.

The five stages of emotions a person may go through when losing a loved one are often referred to as the KÃ¼bler-Ross model or the "five stages of grief." These stages are not experienced linearly or uniformly by everyone; rather, they provide a general framework to understand the complex emotions people may experience during the grieving process. The five stages are:

Denial: In the initial stage of grief, a person may have difficulty accepting the loss. Denial serves as a coping mechanism, allowing the individual to slowly come to terms with the reality of the situation. It can provide a temporary respite from the overwhelming emotions associated with loss.

Anger: As the reality of the loss sets in, a person may experience anger or resentment. This anger can be directed towards themselves, others, or even the person who has passed away. This stage often occurs as the grieving individual struggles to make sense of the situation and searches for someone or something to blame for their pain.

Bargaining: In this stage, the person may attempt to regain control of their situation by making deals with a higher power or their own conscience. They may have thoughts like, "If only I had done this, they would still be here." Bargaining is a way for the individual to process their guilt and find ways to alleviate their emotional pain.

Depression: As the full weight of the loss becomes more apparent, a person may experience deep sadness, despair, and hopelessness. This stage can manifest itself through symptoms such as loss of appetite, difficulty sleeping, and social withdrawal. Depression is a natural response to the immense pain of losing a loved one, and it may take time for the individual to work through their feelings.

Acceptance: Eventually, a person may reach a stage of acceptance, where they are able to acknowledge the reality of their loss and begin to move forward with their life. This stage does not necessarily mean that the person is "over" their grief, but rather that they have learned to live with it and integrate it into their life. Acceptance allows the individual to find new meaning and build a new life without the presence of their loved one.

It is essential to note that people grieve in different ways, and the experience of these stages may vary significantly between individuals. Some may not experience all the stages, while others may go through them in a different order or revisit certain stages multiple times. The grieving process is unique to each person and should be approached with patience, understanding, and support.

Online shopping is a form of electronic commerce which allows consumers to purchase goods or services over the Internet by clicking a mouse without stepping out of their home. With high quality and lower price, online goods attract an increasing number of customers. Meanwhile, online shopping can be conducted anywhere at any time, so it's very convenient and quite fits the young generation's taste. It is predicted that in the future the number of online shoppers will keep growing in China at a faster rate. But the rapid growth of online shopping presents a lot of challenges for the express service. To deliver the massive number of items ordered online to the customers on time, many couriers have to work day and night.

answer: With the large-scale grid connection of new energy stations and the widespread use of power electronic equipment, voltage dip problems in the power grid are becoming more and more serious. Voltage dips can lead to sensitive equipment damage, disruption of industrial production, and huge economic losses, especially in high-tech industries that heavily rely on power electronic devices. Although voltage dips are unavoidable, accurate identification of voltage dip types and localization of voltage dip sources can help mitigate and address the issues they cause. Accurate identification of voltage dip types can assist power companies in quickly clearing faults according to the type of disturbance source, reducing operating costs. Localization of voltage dip sources can define the responsibilities of power suppliers and consumers, providing power companies with control methods. However, the complexity and variability of voltage dip disturbance sources have greatly increased the difficulty of identification and localization. While scholars worldwide have proposed numerous methods for voltage dip identification and localization, most algorithms do not consider waveform distortion issues caused by transformers, leading to inaccurate identification and localization of voltage dip types. Therefore, it is necessary to develop more accurate algorithms for voltage dip identification and localization. This paper focuses on three aspects: voltage dip types and influencing factors, voltage dip type identification, and voltage dip source localization.

Title: "The Quest for Eltheria"

Story Outline:

I. Introduction
A. Introduce protagonist, James "Jim" Watson, a renowned explorer and historian.
B. Jim receives a mysterious letter from an anonymous source, which hints at the existence of the lost civilization of Eltheria.
C. Intrigued, Jim decides to embark on a journey to uncover the truth about Eltheria.
D. Jim assembles a diverse team: Maria, a linguist; Henry, a cartographer; and Lily, an archaeologist.

II. The Journey Begins
A. The team sets out for the Amazon rainforest, where the ancient map in the mysterious letter leads them.
B. Along the way, they encounter various challenges and dangers, including wild animals, treacherous terrain, and harsh weather conditions.
C. Jim and Maria begin to develop feelings for each other, while Henry and Lily form a strong friendship.
D. The team discovers an ancient temple, which holds the first clue to finding Eltheria.

III. Deciphering the Clues
A. Maria uses her linguistic skills to translate the ancient texts found in the temple, revealing more about Eltheria's history and culture.
B. Henry deduces the location of the next clue from the map and ancient texts, leading the team to an underwater cavern.
C. The team faces new challenges as they dive into the depths of the cavern, encountering strange sea creatures and underwater traps.
D. They uncover the second clue, which points them towards a hidden valley in the mountains.

IV. The Hidden Valley
A. The team braves treacherous mountain paths and harsh weather to reach the valley.
B. As they explore the valley, they encounter remnants of Eltherian culture and technology, far more advanced than anything they've seen before.
C. Jim, Maria, Henry, and Lily face their personal fears and insecurities, growing closer as a team.
D. They discover the entrance to Eltheria, hidden behind a waterfall.

V. The Lost City of Eltheria
A. The team enters the city, marveling at the magnificent architecture and advanced technology.
B. They uncover the tragic story of Eltheria's downfall due to a catastrophic event that forced the inhabitants to abandon their home.
C. Maria and Jim confess their love for each other, while Henry and Lily solidify their friendship.
D. The team is confronted by the descendants of the Eltherians, who have been living in secret, guarding their city from outsiders.

VI. The Decision
A. The Eltherian descendants are initially hostile, but Jim and his team manage to gain their trust by sharing their findings and respecting their culture.
B. The team must decide whether to keep the secret of Eltheria to protect the descendants or to reveal it to the world, potentially disrupting their lives.
C. After much deliberation, they decide to keep the secret, believing that the knowledge and experience they've gained will help them make the world a better place.
D. The team departs Eltheria, promising to safeguard its secret.

VII. Epilogue
A. Jim, Maria, Henry, and Lily return to their respective lives, forever changed by their experiences.
B. They remain close friends, united by their shared adventure and the secret of Eltheria.
C. The team continues to work together, using their newfound wisdom and knowledge to make a positive impact on the world.
D. The legend of Eltheria remains hidden, but its spirit lives on in the hearts of the brave explorers.

question:
I have a recipe in englisch. Can you give me a german translation and german measurements with it?

INGREDIENTS
Sweet & Sour Crispy Tofu 

2 tbs Sesame Oil

1 Block Extra Firm Tofu, cubed

3 tbs Cornflour 

5 Spring Onions, chopped small

1 Red Chilli, chipped fine 

3 Cloves Garlic, minced 

1 cup/170g Fresh Pineapple, peeled & cubed  

3 tbs Soy Sauce or Tamari, if gluten free 

Sauce 

1 cup/240ml Pineapple Juice 

2 tbs Sriracha 

2 tbs Tomato Puree Or Ketchup 

2 tbs Caster Sugar or Maple Syrup 

Pinch Sea Salt 

2 tbs Cornflour, mixed with 4 tbs Water 

Serve with 

Rice 

Spring Onions, chopped fine 

METHOD 
Add all the sauce ingredients to a small saucepan except for the cornflour + water mixture. Place the pan over a low heat & whisk together well. Leave the sauce to come to a simmer. 

Meanwhile for the tofu, pre heat a non stick frying pan over a medium heat with a little sesame oil. 

Toss the tofu cubes with the cornflour in a mixing bowl then place them into the pan. 

Stir fry the tofu along with the garlic, spring onion & chilli. When tofu is golden add the pineapple cubes & soy sauce. 

Whisk in the cornflour + water mixture to the sauce to thicken it up. 

Add a couple of spoonfuls of sauce to the tofu to glaze it up before serving the sweet & sour tofu on a bed of rice. 

I like to serve the remaining sauce on the side. 

Garnish with a few chopped spring onions & greens of your choice.

The idea that "everyone is a philosopher" can be seen as both reasonable and unreasonable, depending on how we define philosophy and what we expect from a philosopher. Here are some arguments for both perspectives:

Reasonable:

Inherent curiosity: Human beings are naturally curious, constantly asking questions about the world around them and seeking meaning in their lives. Philosophy is fundamentally about asking and exploring such questions. In this sense, everyone can be considered a philosopher as they engage in critical thinking and attempt to understand the world.

Everyday philosophical discussions: People often engage in conversations and debates about moral, ethical, and existential topics. These discussions, even if informal, reflect philosophical inquiry and can indicate that everyone is, to some extent, a philosopher.

Personal worldview: Everyone has a unique perspective on life, informed by their experiences, beliefs, and values. This personal worldview could be seen as a philosophical stance, making everyone a philosopher by default.

Unreasonable:

Lack of formal education: Professional philosophers typically have extensive formal education in the field, which provides them with a deep understanding of philosophical theories, concepts, and methodologies. Most people lack this formal training, and therefore might not be considered philosophers in the traditional sense.

Incomplete knowledge: Philosophy is a vast and complex discipline, encompassing various branches such as ethics, metaphysics, epistemology, and more. Not everyone has a comprehensive understanding of these fields, which might limit their ability to engage in informed philosophical discussions.

Superficial engagement: While it is true that people may engage in philosophical discussions, many may not delve deeply into the subject matter, nor critically assess their own beliefs or those of others. Such superficial engagement may not qualify someone as a philosopher.

In conclusion, whether or not everyone is a philosopher depends on how one defines a philosopher and the expectations associated with that label. If we consider philosophy as the natural curiosity and basic questioning of life, it is reasonable to say that everyone is a philosopher. However, if we define a philosopher as someone with extensive knowledge and formal education in the field, then the idea becomes less reasonable.

Brian: Are you worried about something? You seem really focused. Maybe I can help you.

Steve: I think I just have to rely on myself. Right now, I just need someone to talk to, to help me relieve some stress.

question:
translate the text into Korean and provide a summary.
Text: ###
Operations to defend the embattled eastern city of Bakhmut will go on, and are backed by senior generals, Ukraine President Volodymyr Zelensky has said.

Western analysts suggested at the weekend that Ukraine was probably withdrawing some of its troops, as Russian forces close in on the city.

Moscow has been trying to take Bakhmut for months, as both sides suffer heavy losses in a grinding war of attrition.

A local official says there has been street fighting in recent days.

But Deputy Mayor Oleksandr Marchenko said at the weekend that Russia had not yet gained control of the city.

Meanwhile Yevgeny Prigozhin, head of the Wagner private army involved in the Russian campaign, has complained of a lack of ammunition amid apparent friction between his fighters and regular Russian forces.

He also says his representative had been barred from a Russian military headquarters.

Analysts say Bakhmut has little strategic value but has become a focal point for Russian commanders who have struggled to deliver any positive news to the Kremlin.

Capture of the city would bring Russia slightly closer to its goal of controlling the whole of Donetsk region, one of four regions in eastern and southern Ukraine it annexed last September after referendums widely condemned outside Russia as a sham.

Fighting to stay Ukrainian in a frontline mining town
Has Putin's war in Ukraine failed?
Mr Zelensky said in his evening address that he had discussed Bakhmut with senior generals.

"[They] responded not to withdraw, but to strengthen [our defences]," he said.

"The command unanimously supported this position. There were no other positions. I told the commander in chief to find the appropriate forces to help our guys in Bakhmut."

The comments followed a report by the German newspaper Bild quoting Ukrainian government sources that armed forces commander Valery Zaluzhny had disagreed with Mr Zelensky about the operation several weeks ago, recommending a retreat from the city.

Most defenders shared Gen Zaluzhny's view, the paper added.

And at the weekend the US-based think tank the Institute for the Study of War (ISW) said Ukrainian troops were probably conducting a "limited fighting withdrawal" while "continuing to inflict high casualties" on the Russians.

Ground forces commander Olexandr Syrsky, quoted on a visit to the front line on Sunday by Ukrainska Pravda newspaper, said the fighting in Bakhmut had reached the "highest level of tension".

"The enemy has been throwing extra Wagner forces into the battle," he said. "Our troops have been courageously defending our positions in the north of Bakhmut, trying to prevent the encirclement of the city."
